blog.name: hopelesstvaddict
blog.title: worry about the past. the future can wait.
blog.description:
No need to know the nAme. 
Swoon and marvel at simple things.
LOST defined life. Live in the Enchanted Forest. Love what happens in Westeros. Wish you could hang out in Rosewood with some pretty little liars. Agonize over the events in Beacon Hills. And so on. Unconditional Cut & Run, Titanic and LOTR lover. 
Proud Princess Aurora, Sansa Stark and Alison Dilaurentis supporter.

summary: Sansa doesn't have a theme like the other characters you named because she was never that important as a character, D&D gave her...
question: Sansa doesn't have a theme like the other characters you named because she was never that important as a character, D&D gave her more importance in the show that what she has in the books
answer: Perhaps. We’ll see about that. Still the soundtrack follows the show right ? It can’t follow the book after all. So I’d be interested in an analysis from Djawadi on why he created specific character themes for some and not for others. And that applies not only to Sansa, who, by your own admission, does have some importance in the show at least but also to Bran, Tyrion or Jaime for example who have all managed to make it to the end and like Sansa, still don’t have themes of their own aside from the Stark and Lannister themes. And in terms of importance, these three do hold importance both in the books and in the show - and yet …

summary: Is there a chance that someone from Stark kids will die next season? I'm quite sure Sansa is surviving, but don't know about...
question: Is there a chance that someone from Stark kids will die next season? I'm quite sure Sansa is surviving, but don't know about Bran and Arya. Especially Arya.
answer: I think when they killed Rickon, they were done killing Starks. Sansa, Bran and Arya are safe. The last season will see them using their skills for a common goal.

reblog.comment: I think when they killed Rickon, they were done killing Starks. Sansa, Bran and Arya are safe. The last season will see them using their skills for a common goal.

trail.content_raw: I think when they killed Rickon, they were done killing Starks. Sansa, Bran and Arya are safe. The last season will see them using their skills for a common goal.
trail.content: I think when they killed Rickon, they were done killing Starks. Sansa, Bran and Arya are safe. The last season will see them using their skills for a common goal.

blog.name: fedonciadale
blog.title: FedonCiadale
blog.description: Fantasy aficionado since I read Tolkien in my teenage years. I still love Tolkien but I am also into other works. I love ASOIAF (books) and GoT (Show). I also like Brandon Sanderson, Lois McMaster Bujold, in short in my free time it's fantasy...Header by courtesy of ragekitn!

summary: Hey, Thanks for answering my question and showing me that d@ny & storm meta. I intend to portray jon as a heroic but also...
question: Hey, Thanks for answering my question and showing me that d@ny & storm meta. I intend to portray jon as a heroic but also destructive savior where if he is not calm he will cause more destruction than the enemy, just like a dragon does, so he represents both wind(unstoppable) and storm(devastating). I am not very well versed with lotr so could you tell me if bloodraven is more like saruman or an evil gandalf or an entirely different figure? I treat him as a friend of humanity but not the heroes.
answer:
Hi there!

I do think that any wielder of magic in ASOIAF has a destructive force as well. So, Jon destroying some things while saving the world from Euron makes sense to me.

Bloodraven…. Well, I do think he is more of a Saruman figure, although in a way he is not. Tolkien made no secret about Saruman’s fall. We learn about Saruman and his own evil agenda when Gandalf tells everyone at Elrond’s council how they were betrayed. So there is no element of surprise there, not really.

With Bloodraven I would say that the motives are similar to Saruman. If my hunch is right he was recruited by the Children of the Forest and managed to dupe them. He then made Euron his apprentice, but he went rogue and then Bloodraven reached out to Bran. But his motives are not selfless and my suspicion is that he wants to use the magic that was let lose with the re-emerging of the WW to get immortality. He might be after a young, male Targ he can inhabit, and my suspicion is, that he is after Jon. He might also be the person who is behind Aegon’s V obsession with dragons and the tragedy of Summerhall. So his motives are selfish and in this regard he is like Saruman, only it is not that obvious to the reader.

An evil Gandalf would not necessarily be selfish, but more like a smaller “dark lord”, in a way more frightening and more surreal than Saruman. So I think I would stick to Saruman as a parallel, even though Bloodraven’s treason is not as easily seen as Saruman’s.

Thanks for the ask!

summary: I enjoyed your Prophecies ask.  Any thought to Jaime being valonqar via Bran warging into him?  Both would meet the younger...
question: I enjoyed your Prophecies ask.  Any thought to Jaime being valonqar via Bran warging into him?  Both would meet the younger brother aspect of her or YMBQ's. I see Cersei's death as very personal.  Bran getting retribution for Broken Tower on having Jaime kill Cersei seems very fitting both for Jaime (making him live with doing this because I'm not sure if he could do it on his own) and obv Cersei. Two birds.  He's one of the only main characters who has not gotten to slay his own demons.
answer:
Hey, nonnie!

Thank you. :)

I know that Bran being the valonqar through warging is a theory that has recently began circulating. The first meta I read on the subject is from @lostlittlesatellites and she makes some interesting points. So I would definitely not dismiss it outright. 

However, I don’t particularly ascribe to this theory and less so to Bran warging Jaime specifically. In a narrative sense, I think it would be a cop out to simultaneously have Jaime kill Cersei but not really because it’s actually Bran doing it. I think with the idea of Jaime as the valonqar, the only way to make it effective, personal and for it to have the tragic narrative impact that I believe such a plot twist would have is to fully commit to it and have Jaime kill her for his own reasons, reasons that should not, by the way, be connected to Brienne in any way. 

I don’t know if you are familiar with Pascal Bruckner’s “Lunes de fiel”. In essence that book is about a couple involved in the most extreme version of a toxic relationship you can imagine and the ending of it finds both of them crippled and disfigured at each other’s hands. In a way that’s how I see the Jaime/Cersei relationship. There is love there but they also hurt and use each other in abhorrent ways so the Jaime as the valonqar theory feels like the satisfying end to their relationship. It’s personal, it’s painful, it’s the toxic end to a relationship that has harmed and twisted both of them. In that sense, I believe there’s also a chance that Jaime will die alongside her. 

As for this: 

Bran getting retribution for Broken Tower on having Jaime kill Cersei seems very fitting both for Jaime (making him live with doing this because I’m not sure if he could do it on his own) and obv Cersei. Two birds. He’s one of the only main characters who has not gotten to slay his own demons.

I’m not really all that comfortable with the idea of revenge and retribution being connected to slaying your demons. And we’ve seen in this story that it actually doesn’t work out that way.

 Does Arya killing the Freys help her heal? She follows that up with threatening to cut her sister’s face off. 

Does killing Ramsay help Sansa move beyond the abuse that was inflicted on her? She’s still cutting herself off, still reluctant to let people in and warping her body in a clothing cage. 

Does executing the Night’s watch brothers help Jon move past his assassination? He’s still haunted by it, as he’s haunted by the execution of Ollie, in particular. 

Killing people does not slay demons or help one heal. Working on yourself, taking time to process your trauma and being around people who love you and care for you, ends up slaying your demons. So in a way the thing that would help Bran the most is, just like all the other Starks, his pack. 

Thanks for the ask!

summary: I also love the King Bran endgame but it also means Sansa has to leave Winterfell. But if the show really leads to book end I'm...
question: I also love the King Bran endgame but it also means Sansa has to leave Winterfell. But if the show really leads to book end I'm convinced there will be no Winterfell in the end and perhaps North too. (We've alredy seen filming photos, Winterfell will be destroyed). So maybe Stark children will be forced to find another home
answer:
Not necessarily. I think GRRM wrote Sansa as having the biggest connection to the South for a reason and I also think she’ll be in a position of power at the end of the books. Also Bran being king doesn’t mean Sansa has to leave, she’s a Stark, she can stay if she wants to and become one of his advisors but I think she’ll be doing something else.

As for that spoiler, unlike book Winterfell, show Winterfell isn’t strong enough to survive the Night King but I’m certain they’ll rebuild Winterfell again. It’s been the Stark home for thousands of years. Also they’re not building a new set just for a few scenes.

summary: The reason I think Bran will become King in the North by the end of the series is that not only is he Ned’s trueborn son, he has...
body: The reason I think Bran will become King in the North by the end of the series is that not only is he Ned’s trueborn son, he has also never left the North, he was lord of Winterfell before its destruction, his powers are tied to the North and he’s being groomed to save it from an ancient enemy. Not to mention he was named after Brandon the Builder. I’m a huge Sansa fan but GRRM has King Bran as the endgame. Hell his first ever chapter he was learning from Ned on how to carry about the king’s justice. He is the only Stark who receives lessons from Ned in the present. That means something.

blog.name: plaidpuppyeyes
blog.title: thanks, it's the anxiety
blog.description:
--Asexual--She/Her--Hufflepuff--ENFJ--Clumsy--Procrastinator--

I am a Christian and my faith is important to me. I believe that showing love and acceptance to people is an enormous part of that. I love and accept all people of all gender identities and sexualities.

Send me ranty asks about anything you see me reblogging and I will happily rant back to you. 
My askbox is always open for whatever you need.

Header by @fiona-catherine

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: asoiaf Bran: *defends his Sansa when everyone else criticized her, worries about his siblings, wishes he could turn into a wolf...
body:
asoiaf Bran: *defends his Sansa when everyone else criticized her, worries about his siblings, wishes he could turn into a wolf to save Sansa and Arya from King’s Landing, described as Cat’s sweetest child, the moment he hated most about losing his ability to walk is when he’s unable to comfort a crying Meera because he can’t reach her*

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: My husband and I had dinner at a friends’ place— they wanted to watch Game of Thrones, so we did. Bran comes on the screen, and...
body:
My husband and I had dinner at a friends’ place— they wanted to watch Game of Thrones, so we did. Bran comes on the screen, and without missing a beat, my husband says “He’s Stark Raven mad.”


I’ve never been more proud of him.

reblog.comment:
My husband and I had dinner at a friends’ place— they wanted to watch Game of Thrones, so we did. Bran comes on the screen, and without missing a beat, my husband says “He’s Stark Raven mad.”


I’ve never been more proud of him.

trail.content_raw:
My husband and I had dinner at a friends’ place— they wanted to watch Game of Thrones, so we did. Bran comes on the screen, and without missing a beat, my husband says “He’s Stark Raven mad.”


I’ve never been more proud of him.
trail.content:
My husband and I had dinner at a friends’ place— they wanted to watch Game of Thrones, so we did. Bran comes on the screen, and without missing a beat, my husband says “He’s Stark Raven mad.”


I’ve never been more proud of him.

summary: Empathy is a characteristic most of the POV characters seem to lack. At least, only sansa, Jon, Davis and Brienne come off as...
question: Empathy is a characteristic most of the POV characters seem to lack. At least, only sansa, Jon, Davis and Brienne come off as empathetic to me. Which other POV characters would you say display empathy on a consistent basis?
answer:
Quite a few of them, together making up most of the novels.

There’s Ned:

“No less do I love mine.”

Ned thought, If it came to that, the life of some child I did not know, against Robb and Sansa and Arya and Bran and Rickon, what would I do? Even more so, what would Catelyn do, if it were Jon’s life, against the children of her body? He did not know. He prayed he never would.

“All three are Jaime’s,” he said.

- Eddard XII, AGoT

There’s Catelyn:

Small wonder her sister’s marriage had been so loveless. The Arryns were proud, and prickly of their honor. Lord Jon might wed Lysa to bind the Tullys to the cause of the rebellion, and in hopes of a son, but it would have been hard for him to love a woman who came to his bed soiled and unwilling. He would have been kind, no doubt; dutiful, yes; but Lysa needed warmth.

- Catelyn I, ASoS

There’s Tyrion:

Robb Stark seemed puzzled. “Is this some trap, Lannister? What’s Bran to you? Why should you want to help him?”

“Your brother Jon asked it of me. And I have a tender spot in my heart for cripples and bastards and broken things.” Tyrion Lannister placed a hand over his heart and grinned.

- Bran IV, AGoT

There’s Bran:

“What do you think?” his father asked.

Bran thought about it. “Can a man still be brave even if he’s afraid?”

- Bran I, AGoT

There’s Daenerys:

“Better to come a beggar than a slaver,” Arstan said.

“There speaks one who has been neither.” Dany’s nostrils flared. “Do you know what it is like to be sold, squire? I do. My brother sold me to Khal Drogo for the promise of a golden crown. Well, Drogo crowned him in gold, though not as he had wished, and I…my sun-and-stars made a queen of me, but if he had been a different man, it might have been much otherwise. Do you think I have forgotten how it felt to be afraid?”

- Daenerys II, ASoS

And there’s Arya:

“All gods have their instruments, men and women who serve them and help to work their will on earth. The slaves were not crying out to a hundred different gods, as it seemed, but to one god with a hundred different faces…and he was that god’s instrument. That very night he chose the most wretched of the slaves, the one who had prayed most earnestly for release, and freed him from his bondage. The first gift had been given.”

Arya drew back from him. “He killed the slave?” That did not sound right. “He should have killed the masters!”

- Arya II, AFFC

Nobody’s empathy is perfect. They have blind spots and bad days. They all live in a system that often actively discourages empathy. But these characters all show it.

blog.name: winterfellchild
blog.title: The pack survives
blog.description:
"She (Daenerys) has the power to destroy, she can wipe out entire cities, and we
certainly see that in ‘Fire and Blood.’ We see the dragons wiping out 
entire armies, wiping out towns and cities, destroying them, but that 
doesn’t necessarily enable you to rule — it just enables you to destroy." GRRM

summary: Second picture in a long term ASOIAF fan art project. This illustration is based on the following passage from Bran VI in A Game...
caption:
Second picture in a long term ASOIAF fan art project. This illustration is based on the following passage from Bran VI in A Game of Thrones, by George R. R. Martin (1996) -

“Summer lapped at the water and settled down at Bran’s side. He rubbed the wolf under the jaw, and for a moment boy and beast both felt at peace. Bran had always liked the godswood, even before, but of late he found himself drawn to it more and more. Even the heart tree no longer scared him the way it used to. The deep red eyes carved into the pale trunk still watched him, yet somehow he took comfort from that now. The gods were looking over him, he told himself; the old gods, gods of the Starks and the First Men and the children of the forest, his father’s gods. He felt safe in their sight, and the deep silence of the trees helped him think. Bran had been thinking a lot since his fall; thinking, and dreaming, and talking with the gods.”

summary: About Sansa's endgame, do you think it's possible for her to be the Queen/Lady of Winterfell? Her being a Regent for Rickon...
question: About Sansa's endgame, do you think it's possible for her to be the Queen/Lady of Winterfell? Her being a Regent for Rickon would be great, but her entire arc being political makes me more inclined for her to be the sole ruler, instead of Bran or Rickon. GRRM highlighted the fact that there's never been a female ruler of Winterfell multiple times, and if the series doesn't end with a woman as Winterfell's leader (not a consort or a Regent) it would be almost disappointing
answer: Possible? Certainly. But I’m personally not keen on sacrificing Bran (to the astral plane) and Rickon to have Sansa become Lady of Winterfell. But I’m very attached to the idea that Sansa might be the Stark that holds Winterfell during the thick of the War for the Dawn, and I do think her story arc strongly supports her ruling in some capacity. Personally, I’d love nothing more than for the surviving Starklings to work as a unit post-war. Give me Bran the Rebuilder using his magical knowledge to rebuild Winterfell and the North. Give me Sansa taking on the day-to-day ruling and her ancestors’ historical duty to care and provide for her people. Give me Arya being the North’s protector and warrior. Rebuild, provide and protect. I’m in love with the idea of them being a ruling unit that embodies the very role Winterfell was built for, each with their own area of expertise to reflect their current training montages.
